Compelled! The superb Kanban, which allows us to experience vehicle development in a playful way, compelled us to purchase another game by Vital Lacerda. The good reviews, which promise a complex gourmet game, compelled us to pick up On Mars. The extensive, cumbersome, and confusing rules compelled us to play a few times to make sure we were playing correctly. The few options for action in orbit and on Mars left us with few choices and, in combination with the situation in the game, compelled us to do what had to be done. Detailed rules compelled us to perform certain actions that triggered specific effects. Random elements in the form of bonus tiles, target cards, and card displays compelled us to pay attention to the few possible actions. Finally, the final scoring compelled one person to win who did not even know how they had achieved it.
Some games use complexity to offer rich possibilities, perhaps even a wide variety of strategies that we can try out, but On Mars uses complexity to make it as difficult as possible for us to execute a move that is compelled by the circumstances anyway. There are no greatly differing strategies; the only difference is in the color of the tiles that we are then compelled to choose. It is a tedious game that remains tedious and does not open up any unexpected possibilities, as we are used to from some other complex games.

It is funny how an over convoluted game with confusing rules and bad iconography can still get 8.2 on BGG. It shows that people are incapable of distinguishing between complexity of a game's strategic elements and the quality of its design.

People think it is complex because it is difficult to learn. No, my friends, that simply means it is poorly designed. A game can have a lot of elements that work together making the game complex, but these elements should never be difficult to understand. It is the designers role to make things accessible to the players. This is what distinguish good designers from the bad.

On Mars is simply another example on how many poorly designed games are promoted to top on BGG because people thinks difficult to learn means a good game.

On Mars is a heavy game where players must unlock the puzzle of a multi-step procedure to get to a strategic decision. Now I like complex games but this one feels like assembling a piece of Ikea furniture. Can I follow the instructions and use an Allen key to build a book shelf. You betcha. Does that bring me any satisfaction or payoff? Nope. Instead, the instruction set and process of assembly gets in the way of the game, making On Mars seem way more complex than it really is. And most of the time, this procedure is not worth the payoff. I thought the on-world, off-world mechanic was smart. I liked the concept of collaborative building of a colony together and getting rewarded for your contributions to a common goal. But there are so many inorganic mechanics shoved into this design that seem tacked on. Take the rover/lander action for example. This could have been solved with two simple rules: 1) you may build next to or one away from an existing construct of yours; 2) upon returning to Mars, take a reward. Instead, I have to take the action which lets me move and possibly spend additional resources to get where I need to go. Thematically it works. Design wise, it gets in the way. Look, I am not a Vital Lacerda junkie. I really liked CO2 when it first came out but haven’t played it in a while. I enjoy Vinhos if someone else does the teach. But of his recent designs, everything has been a let down for me. I appreciate the feat. I really do. But his games are not for me. I would rather play the game, than figure out how to unlock tasks to play the game.

I could describe why some people enjoy this one. I just can't empathize with that appeal.

Setup and teach could legitimately take an hour if you're being thorough and not trying to rush new players through the game's ideas. Even with longtime gamers, this was well over 30 minutes for us.

That also points to the game's fiddly rules density. I can acknowledge there's some strategic brain-burn hiding underneath it all, as well as depth, but I disagree that its mechanical opulence equates to more depth than many that get to the interesting stuff more quickly and without all the work.

This is also a game where some components' only function is to remind you of a mechanic. And various strategy articles recommend methods of remembering to do stuff...not methods do things well, just to do them at all. When a good strategy, worth repeating across multiple threads, is "try to remember the rules," something is off.

Obviously this is shouting into the wind against a very popular game on BGG, and I wish its fans well. But I'd just as soon skip it and merely hang out and chat, or go home and return on a different game night with a game that's actually fun for me.

This is a worker placement game where you have a pawn that during between rounds phases can move between the space action area and the mars action area, giving you different action options depending where you are. In space you collect resources and power up your abilities and on mars you walk your robots around the map making buildings and factories.

This is a very accessible game compared to some of the other games by Vital. It has a little bit of his hallmark complication, but it has none of the between turns or kicked out action qwirks. Overall entertaining, but even the minor elements of over-complication put this on the would-play-more list but not the must-play-more list.

Shuttle mechanic is clever but building / upgrade rules are just overwrought (if you have A, then you need B, and don't forget C, D and E). Iconography is extremely confusing - I lost count of the number of times I got what I thought a 'scoring' card was telling me wrong. Tech and what benefits it allows at each level is also pretty opaque. A ton of jigsaw pieces that never made a coherent picture.

A modern Lacerda game where the complexity of the rules outweighs the significance of the decisions you make. It feels more like an abstract puzzle packed with mechanisms and icons, but offers relatively little enjoyment in actual gameplay. It lacks the elegance and smooth flow found in his earlier titles, such as Vinhos or Kanban. Too long and little interaction for my taste too.

The orbit-surface refresh tempo is super cool, up there with the the Empyreal conductor track in what a cool jerky syncopated action puzzle it is. Everything that actually happens on mars is boring.

It's pretty complicated, but it's not exactly tight in the same way Imperial Steam or Smokey valley is tight. Your plans are only ever loose, you have no real needs.
Obvious needs are some of the most interesting things in games. They constrain and differentiate the narrative arc of any one play of solo games, and they are the single biggest piece of information exchanged in an interactive game. When players have needs it can force negotiation in negotiation games. In shared-space/resources games it gives you a clear dotted line through future turns you know they'll trace so you can decide to wheel your ship away to plunder some other part of the game freely, or to steer into them and interfere.

Players goals at any point in time are difficult to project forward, given all the machinery that stands between you and your next turn. It's not clear if a multiplayer game can be found underneath all this mechanical fog.

Also at the end of the day you're just grubbing for points?

I Generally feel like this game is a bit too tight. I don't mind tight games but this one really feels to me like it is prohibitive. As a player you are constantly managing constraints. You lack a certain resource, you don't have enough available storage space, you have just one action per turn.. etc etc.

The start of the game is quite constricted and limited and early on you will often find that executing whatever plan you have isn't going to be straightforward and you often require several turns and actions to achieve any set goals. You generally get the feeling that you find yourself doing what you can do and making the best of that rather than devising a clear strategy and executing. Executing a strategy requires a lot of build up in general and you will often find yourself running through your constraints. You would like to build but require the resource. The resource isn't available in the warehouse so you need to either build a certain other building to get it or maybe claim an iss bonus mineral. Unfortunately now you realize that you don't have the resource required to gain said bonus or build said building but it can be found in the warehouse so you can use an executive action. If only you had the crystals for that action. Ok you can build a house to get a crystal and grab the resource you need. Great now next turn you can build the building to get the resource to actually build what you are aiming to. Next turn you want to build but because there are meeples on the action it costs more crystals. if you have the crystals you forgot that you lack the workers to do the action. You gain workers and next turn the spot you wanted to build is now taken. etc etc.

The game is too tight. It isn't too tight to handle, in fact I have generally played the game quite well, but it is too tight to be very fun. The complexity budget is used in a negative way. 90% of the thinking is put in to working around the many limitations that you need to manage rather than in to building something positive like an engine. Getting up and running is just about when you can start to act more freely without hitting walls constantly. Unfortunately by the time you get there the game is just about over. You spend most of the game crawling out of a hole and just when you feel like you start to scale up the game ends. You spend the game building something but hardly get to expolit what you built. To make it worse most of the points you will earn don't come from the engine but from technologies and awards. The game end never really feels great. The game manages to feel too long and end too quickly at the same time. In most of our games the winner never actually really felt like the player that managed to achieve the thematic goal of the game. Thematic integration is a huge staple for VL games but in this one I feel the disconnect in the scoring even if it is embedded expertly in to the mechanics.

I think I can sum up this game as follows: Lacerda was too concerned with how complex a game he could make but never stopped to consider where he should make it that complex. It is a genius bit of game design and I am in awe of how intricate the game is and how thematic the gameplay elements are. Objectively this is a masterpiece but in 4 plays it was never actually fun for everyone at the table. It tends to frustrate at least one player every single time. Fantastic design but not actually very fun. Psychologically I think good play isn't properly rewarded and bad play is severely punished. This game would be a lot better if it was just a bit less tight and gave players some wiggle room. Tight games tend to confine players in to certain strategems or actions and reduce creative freedom.

Crushingly complex. Absolutely beautiful components & board. And one of the most touching gifts I've ever received. Glorious.

PROS:
- Complex but very interesting puzzle
- The rocket mechanic forces you to commit whether going to the other side is important, especially when considering that other players staying are taking more actions to reduce the limited actions on the board
- Lots of tension as people will very quickly take resources/techs/blueprints off the board before you can get it, and you're dealing with very little resources at times
- The turn order mechanic borrows the awesome mechanic of Viticulture, where there are benefits to going last
- Scientists add a lot of combo potential. and being able to use someone else's scientist adds a lot of immediacy and tactical consideration
- Not completing buildings and getting minus points adds a lot of tension to the already limited spaces on the board
- Tech powers add a neat element of tableau and power building
- Crystals and rockets adds a lot of combo making potential
- Lots of feel-good moments as you connect same-type buildings together, matching the techs to a pattern and completing objectives
- Lost of player interaction as you can use other people's techs, blueprints and racing for tokens on the board
- Tons of replayability due to the variable end-game triggers, techs that show on the board, objectives etc

CONS:
- Very complex and needs at least 2-3 games to get the hang of it
- Very Euro-like interactions, nothing that makes you go "what did you do?!"
- Theme gets drowned by combos and puzzle solving

FINAL THOUGHTS:
When a Lacerda game gets it right, it is really good! Happy to play a friend's copy but probs won't own it myself. Very fun to play repeatedly and get really good at it
